Let's Start

Vision

Our vision is to better explain space and infinity to you. Let's start a journey to get lost with us in the scary, endless vacuum of space! Let's explore the dazzling infinity together.
Do you think we are alone in this infinity? We think that there are many creatures like us in the infinite universe.
We hope they will contact us as soon as possible :)
Isn't it a very long journey to return to where it all started? Discovering billions of stars scattered to infinity after the big bang and discovering new ones as we discover gives us great excitement.

Mars

Mars is the fourth planet of the Solar System from the Sun. It is named after Mars, the god of war in Roman mythology. It is also called the "Red Planet" because it has a reddish appearance due to the widespread iron oxide on its surface. It is a terrestrial planet with an aspect that includes polar regions. Also, its rotation period and seasons are very similar to Earth's. It has 2 satellites. Mount Olympus (Olympus Mons) on Mars is the highest known mountain in the Solar System and the canyon called Marineris Valley (Valles Marineris) is the largest canyon. Also, as described in three articles published in the journal Nature in June 2008, a giant meteor crater 10,600 km long and 8,500 km wide has been detected in the northern hemisphere of Mars. This crater is four times the size of the largest meteor crater ever discovered (Atkien Basin at the Moon's south pole). Today, Mars is home to three spacecraft in orbit: Mars Odyssey, Mars Express, and Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. Mars can be seen with the naked eye from Earth. Area: 144.8 million km² Gravity: 3.721 m/s² Mass: 6.39E23 kg (0.107 M⊕) Coordinates: SA 23s 3d 22s | Load. -7° 45′ 4″ Main axis: 227,939,200 km; (141.634.900 mil; 1.523679 AU) Angular diameter: 3.5–25.1

Venus

Although Venus is not the closest planet to the Sun, it is the hottest. This is because it has an atmosphere containing dense greenhouse gases. This atmosphere is densely composed of clouds of carbon monoxide and sulfuric acid. These gases trap heat from the Sun. Thus, it raises the temperature of Venus. Venus is a very active planet. Venus has mountains and volcanoes on its surface. The dimensions of Venus are very close to Earth. An important feature that distinguishes Venus from other planets is that it rotates around itself in the opposite direction of Earth and many other planets. It takes about 243 Earth days for Venus to complete its rotation. But because it is so close to the Sun, a year passes faster and takes 225 Earth days. A day on Venus is different from that on Earth, as the rotation periods around itself and around the Sun are close to each other. Venus sunrises occur every 117 Earth days, which means that there are only 2 sunrises per year, per Venusian year. Because it rotates in the opposite direction with respect to the Earth, the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east. Area: 460,200,000 km² Gravity: 8.87 m/s² Orbit time: 225 days Mass: 4,867E24 kg (0.815 M⊕) Absolute magnitude: -4.47 Day length: 116 days 18 hours 0 minutes

Jupiter

Jupiter is the largest planet in our Solar System. It has a size close to being a star, but because its size has not reached a certain amount, nuclear reaction has not started in its center. Its atmosphere is covered with swirling cloud lines. There are storms that have been going on for hundreds of years in what is called the "Great Red Spot". Jupiter is a gas giant, so it has no solid surface. At its center is thought to be a solid core the size of the Earth. Jupiter also has rings, but it is too faint to be seen with the naked eye. A day on Jupiter lasts 10 hours, and a Jupiter year is approximately equal to 12 Earth years. Jupiter has 79 confirmed moons, the most famous being Gaynmede, Europa. Area: 6,142E10 km² Age: 4,603E9 years old Mass: 1,898E27 kg (317.8 M⊕) Moons: Europa, Ganymede, Io, Callisto, Amalthea, Himalia, Valetudo

Saturn

Saturn is not the only planet with rings, but it is definitely the most beautiful. The ring we see is made up of a group of small rings joined together. These rings are made up of pieces of ice and rock. Like Jupiter, Saturn is mostly composed of hydrogen and helium. When Galileo Galilei saw Saturn with his telescope in the 1600s, he wasn't sure what he was looking at. At first he thought he was looking at three planets or a planet with ears. But now we know that those ears are Saturn's rings. Saturn is a gas giant just like Jupiter and is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium. It has an intense atmosphere. Saturn is famous for its rings. This planet has 7 rings with spaces between them. On Saturn it lasts 1 day, 10.7 hours. 1 Saturn year is equal to 29 Earth years. Saturn has 53 moons. It also has 29 satellites about which we need more information. Saturn has been known since ancient times, as it can be seen without a telescope. With the developing technology, 4 robotic spacecraft visited Saturn over time. These; Pioneer 11, Cassini, Voyager 1 and 2 are spacecraft. Area: 4.27E10 km² Age: 4,503E9 years old Gravity: 10.44 m/s² Name source: Saturn Major axis: 1,433.53 million km (9.5826 AU) Kurtosis: 0.097 96 Moons: Titan, Enceladus, Mimas, Tethys, Iapetus, Dione, Rhea.

Earth

The third planet of the solar system is our home planet Earth. The only planet known to have living life and liquid water on it, Earth is also the fifth largest planet in the solar system. As a rocky planet, 29% of the Earth is made up of land containing continents and islands, while 71% is composed of the hydrosphere, which includes lakes, rivers and other freshwater resources, mostly oceans. Our adventure on our planet, which has been known to have life for billions of years, began only about 200,000 years ago. Although humanity's adventure on Earth seems very long when compared to human life, it corresponds to a negligible time compared to the age of the Earth. Orbital period:365.256363004 days Cover. orbital speed: 29.78 km/s Cover. separation: 358.617° Tilt: 7.155° (Sun's equator) Axis tilt:23.4392811°

Uranus

Uranus is the 7th planet of the Solar System in order of distance from the Sun. It comes third after Jupiter and Saturn in terms of diameter and fourth in terms of mass after these two planets and Neptune. It is named after the Greek mythology sky god, Uranus (Οὐρανός in Greek, Uranus in its Latin form). It was discovered by William Herschel in 1781 and is classified as an Ice giant. The mass of Uranus is 15 times that of the Earth, and its volume is 63 times that of the Earth. It has been determined that there are 10 thin, sharp lines and dark colored rings around Uranus. All of the rings consist of dark colored rock-like fragments with a diameter of about 1 m. Their structure has not yet been determined. Uranus rotates like a wheel with its pole facing the sun. Thus, the rings around it rotate vertically with it. Area: 8,083E9 km² Age: 4,503E9 years Explorer: William Herschel Axis tilt: 97.77° (to orbit) Major axis: 19.2184 AU Months: Titania, Umbriel, Oberon, Ariel, Miranda, Puck, Cressida,

Neptune

Neptune is the eighth planet in the Solar System, the farthest from the Sun and has no solid surface. Neptune, which is in the gas planets class, is also classified as an ice giant due to its different structure compared to Jupiter and Saturn. It is one of the two coldest planets in the solar system, along with Uranus. Although it does not have a solid surface, the outer layer of the planet is mainly composed of hydrogen and helium. In its inner layer, most of the planet's mass consists of hot and dense substances (water, methane and ammonia) above a rocky core. The planet, named after the Roman god of the sea, Neptunus, is the fourth largest planet in the Solar System by diameter and the third largest by mass. With 17 times more mass than Earth, it is slightly larger and denser than its twin Uranus. Its distance from the Sun is on average 30 Astronomical units. Distance from sun: 4,495E9 km Area: 7,618E9 km² Discovery date: September 23, 1846 Age: 4,503E9 years old Orbit time: 165 years old Known natural satellites: 14 Months: Triton, Hippocamp, Thalassa, Naiad, Nereid, Despina,

Mercury

Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun. It is faster than any other planet in the Solar System, with an orbital period equal to about 88 Earth days. Seen from Earth, it appears to move around its orbit in 116 days. It has no known natural satellites. It takes its name from the Roman god Mercury, the messenger of the gods. Due to almost no atmosphere to retain heat, Mercury's surface temperature changes more daily than any other planet in the Solar System. In some equatorial regions it ranges from 100 K (-173 °C; -280 °F) at night to 700 K (427 °C; 800 °F) during the day. The poles are consistently below 180 K (-93 °C; -136 °F). Mercury's axis is the smallest (about 1⁄30 of a degree) axis tilt in the Solar System. However, Mercury's eccentricity is greater than that of all known planets in the Solar System.[a] It is 1.5 times further from the Sun at the aphelion than at the perihelion. Mercury's surface is heavily cratered and resembles the Moon in appearance. This indicates that it has been geologically inactive for billions of years. Distance from the sun: 57.910.000 km Area: 74,800,000 km² Gravity: 3.7 m/s² Mass: 3.285E23 kg (0.055 M⊕) Absolute magnitude: -0.6 Axis tilt: 2.04′ ± 0.08′ (to orbit); (0.034°) Volume: : 6,083 × 1010 km3; 0.056 Earth;

Sun

The Sun is the star at the center of the Solar System. A medium-sized star, the Sun alone makes up 99.8% of the Solar System mass. The remaining mass consists of planets orbiting the Sun, asteroids, meteorites, comets, and cosmic dust. The energy emitted from the Sun in the form of daylight enables almost all life on Earth to exist through photosynthesis and has significant effects on Earth's climate and weather. One of the estimated 200 billion stars in the Milky Way Galaxy, the Sun's mass consists of hot gases and emits radiation in the form of heat and light to its surroundings. The Sun has approximately 109 times the diameter of the Earth (1.5 million km), 1.3 million times its volume, and 333 thousand times its mass. Its density is ¼ of the density of the Earth. The Sun has an orbit around the Milky Way galaxy, it moves at a speed of 828,000 km/s in this orbit, while moving in orbit, all parts of the planet, meteor etc. in its own system revolve around the Milky Way with the sun. This speed is noticed after a spacecraft has completely exited the solar system, the sun and the solar system will move away from itself as 828,000 km in 1 hour. Equatorial radius: 695,700 km (109 times that of Earth) Equatorial circumference: 4,379×106 km Kurtosis:9×10−6 Surface area: 6,088×1018 m² (11,900 times that of Earth) Volume: 1,4122×1027 m³ (1,300,000 times that of Earth) Mass:1.9891 ×1030 kg (332,946 times that of Earth)
